TLDR: I got this game at 50%, and still feel like it wasn't worth it.

The GoodThe pixelized graphics are quite nice, and the soundtrack is good.

The BadThere's not much content in this game, basically you hunt for all the different endings, which are mostly variations of the pixelized city getting destroyed. There are tons of pop culture references that appeal to the gaming demographic (Illuminati, satanism, Papers Please, and the Stanley Parable to name a few), but if you are looking for any logical explanation why your button presses cause these endings, you are out of luck.

The UglyThere are hints as to how you reach the endings, some hints are quite easy, others are almost impossible to understand without a guide. Problem is, if you use a guide you lose all feeling of accomplishment, and if you don't use a guide, you will get very frustrated. For example, one ending is only achievable if you do a specific thing exactly at midnight, meaning you need to reset your computer clock for this. How was I ever supposed to guess such a thing? Other endings require a massive commitment of time clicking a button 276 times for one ending, and clicking that same button 666 times for another is just not my idea of fun. God forbid that you missed the hint for this from another ending, or clicked one time too many. In that case you would have to do this all over again.

reviewText:
Simple, minimalistic, brilliant and beautiful. That's how I would describe Please, Don't Touch Anything. It's really worth your time and nerves.
Developer: Four Quarters
Publisher: BulkyPix, Plug In Digital
Release Date: 26th March, 2015

Let me start of by saying this. There’s so much one could talk about yet so little.
To be quite honest you shouldn’t even read any Reviews because reading just a tiny bit ‘bout this wonderfully crafted game would turn into a huge spoiler so … FLY YOU FOOL!

Please, Don’t Read Anything!
In case you’re still here … this game is perfect for someone like you who refuses to listen.

Now let’s get this Review going!

Story...?
Your Co-Worker left. Claiming he needs to use the bathroom. No big deal’s what you might be thinking so you’re sitting there and looking around the room just to pass time since you’re not supposed to touch anything. But then all of a sudden … you see this big ol’ Red Button. You feel like it’s staring right at you … looking right into your very soul. It knows you. Better than you know yourself. I have to press it … it commands me to press it. I want it. I want to press it.. Your minds racing. Please, Don’t Touch Anything...

Will you give in to your desire? Or are you strong enough to wait for your Co-Worker to return?

Gameplay
Please, Don’t Touch Anything is a short and easy game. That’s what you might be thinking and you couldn’t be more wrong. It’s a challenging and complex game. Well it is if you’re willing to put time, blood and sweat into it. You might be wondering why so let me explain.

Multiple. Endings. Let that sink in for a minute. Yeah you read that right. The whole game takes place in one room where you’re not supposed to touch anything. So you can either just sit around and stare at whatever you want to stare at the moment or you can go ahead and just … touch everything?

The game’s challenging. The puzzles and riddles aren’t easy let me tell you that. At the same time though, you have everything you need to know right in front of you. The game’s not just throwing you into it saying Have Fun and Good Luck figuring out what to do well I mean actually it does but it’s giving you hints and clues on what to do.
My best advice is: Think outside the box.

Like I said, personally, I find it incredibly hard to give you folks an insight into this complex and really beautiful game without spoiling all the fun but let me just say this. There’s so much to explore and discover. There are so many puzzles and riddles in this game.
It all starts with the big ol’ Red Button.
Okay, okay I’ll say three things which will get you interested. I guarantee it.

Blood. Illuminati. Satan
Right? You’re interested now! I knew it!
I suggest you dive into this game and just play it. You’ll get frustrated and annoyed and whatnot but you’ll always come back to it to discover more.

My jaw literally dropped once in this game. And it takes a lot for that to happen.

I know, I know I haven’t talked too much ‘bout the gameplay but to be honest: I can’t. Not without spoiling all the fun.

Atmosphere
Well we’ve all been there. Either in someone’s car or at someone’s house. All of a sudden they have to take a call or something and leave you all alone. Remember that feeling? Well so do I and it seriously felt like that once you start the game. You sit there and sure you don’t touch anything … then it happens. You get bored. Booooooring. So you proceed to play around.

Now that’s the beauty of the game. You turn back into a child and you just press and hit and click on whatever you can. Unless you’ve been born as a full grown up having manners and all that well then … Good for you. There’s the door.
But for all of us with our inner childs … boy this game is fun.

To make it short. If I had to describe the Atmosphere I’d say it’s exciting boring.
Doubt that makes any sense but hey if you’re looking for something logica then I’m afraid you’re ‘bout to play the wrong game.

Visuals and Sound
Well what can I say? If you’ve read some of my Reviews so far you know that I just love games with a retro look and feeling. I just love me some pixels. The game’s looking beautiful and I really like the few animations it has. Everything works together. There's nothing that I could point at and be like Ah well no this just doesn't feel right. This doesn't sound good. The art is simple and minimalistic but so good.
Especially the sounds make it so much better. For every situation there’s just the perfect sound for it. Overall very pleasing.

What else can I say?
I’ve tried the original Ludum Dare version which was called The Second Thought way before Please, Don’t Touch Anything so I knew exactly what I’m getting myself into … or so I thought. The game’s really enjoyable despite it’s difficulty. But then again … You have everything you need to know right in front of you at all times.
Also never forget! Think outside the box! Look at every detail. Everything is important and has some function in one way or another.
But most importantly. Don’t ask for help. Don’t google how to solve puzzles or how to unlock every ending. You’re just going to ruin the whole game and therefore fun for yourself.
Enjoy being dumb. Enjoy being frustrated. You’ll enjoy it so much more once you finally solved a puzzle and unlocked an ending after resisting the urge to rip your face into tiny bits and pieces just because you couldn’t figure out what to do.

I can’t recommend this game enough. It will stimulate your brain cells and you have to actually think ‘bout what to do and when. That’s the beauty of it.

Let me end by saying

Please, Touch Everything

Well, this is a sweet little game, full with mathematical puzzles and pop culture references including Futurama, V for Vendetta, Illuminati, Dune, Star Wars and a couple others that I don't remember at the time. Sadly, I'm here to point some downsides for the game.

Someone asks you to wait before some machine with a big red button - incredibly predictable, just as human nature - and - wait for it - DO NOT TOUCH THE BUTTON until he returns. Catchy, huh? Being a proper example of the human species, you push the button and face a collection of mathematical puzzles to hunt for all the possible outcomes that the machine might present you. There are 22 separate endings, mainly consisting of different apocalyptic ends for the city on the screen of the machine, and some irrelevant endings. The last ending, contains the main joke of the setting. So far, so good.

The downside is that the game consists of this given scene only. The machine, some puzzles and some endings that you may observe from the screen, flavored with references. That's it. And the price of the game is ridiculous for a 'one scene only' game. I'd love it if I were to stumble it as a free browser game, but for 5 dollars, nope, thank you. If you decide that it's worth your dollar, grab this little brain scratcher. If not, it won't be the most irredeemable miss.

reviewText:
The game costs five and a half bucks, and it gives a bit more than five and a half buks worth of entertainment.

The game has 16 endings, acquired through pressing certain things on the panel and such.

The tricky solutions are usually based off of creative thinking, with maybe a little bit of help from google here and there to understand some of the concepts (unless you already know the Fibonacci sequence). But some of the endings are obtained through simply fiddling with the controls on the panel.
Speaking of creative thinking, the instructions on the wall are actually helpful and will let you know how to get some of the endings if you're thinking the right way.

It feels good when you find an ending by yourself, but I don't blame you if you give up and just look up a walkthrough; it is super cryptic, after all.

Overall, it's fun and oddly charming. It's pretty confusing, but that's the point.

And yes, there is an ending for not pressing anything.

reviewText:
Please, Don't Touch Anything is a puzzle game, and a very interesting little curiosity. You're asked to watch over this box with a large, red button, and asked not to touch anything. The magic begins when you press the button, and more controls open up. Doing certain things opens up more controls and more ways to interact with the box, and your goal is to get each of the possible endings by performing specific tasks.

The problem is that the things that need to be done are not at all straightforward. You'll have to use your puzzle-solving skills and your curiosity to see all of the content. You'll have to hunt for clues and find out what to do with them.

I enjoyed this game, but I don't think it's for everyone. If you don't have the patience to work through riddles, this game probably isn't for you, but if you do, then it's probably worth the $5. I'd definitely recommend avoiding walkthroughs until you're really stuck... there are some pretty tough ones, though, and some of the clues are difficult to find.

As for the soundtrack, I think I'd recommend playing the game before making that decision. The tracks are nice, but most of the game's music is fairly ambient. With full hindsight, I probably wouldn't have spent money on it, but that's because it doesn't appeal to my tastes... your mileage may vary.

reviewText:
The game costs five and a half bucks, and it gives a bit more than five and a half buks worth of entertainment.

The game has 16 endings, acquired through pressing certain things on the panel and such.

The tricky solutions are usually based off of creative thinking, with maybe a little bit of help from google here and there to understand some of the concepts (unless you already know the Fibonacci sequence). But some of the endings are obtained through simply fiddling with the controls on the panel.
Speaking of creative thinking, the instructions on the wall are actually helpful and will let you know how to get some of the endings if you're thinking the right way.

It feels good when you find an ending by yourself, but I don't blame you if you give up and just look up a walkthrough; it is super cryptic, after all.

Overall, it's fun and oddly charming. It's pretty confusing, but that's the point.

And yes, there is an ending for not pressing anything.

reviewText: I bought this game the day it came out, based on the premise alone. This is something I rarely do, but I'm glad I risked the five dollars. It is a very entertaining diversion, and is also a lot of fun to share with friends. The art style is sure to draw comparisons to Papers Please (another excellent and original game), but that is where the similarity ends. Please, Don't Touch Anything is a puzzle game, and a rather devious one at that. I would highly recommend playing through it without looking at any forums or guides, as the process of figuring out how to get all the possible endings IS the game. Some take some thought, but the answers to all of the puzzles are in front of you the whole time; you just have to look hard enough. I really enjoyed playing this game. It took me about 3 hours to get all endings and all achievements. Highly recommended.

reviewText: This is a fantastic, quirky, absorbing game which will tickle your brain and give you arthritis of the index finger from so much mouse clicking. But in a good way. The retro pixel art style is lovely, there are some top notch little animations as well—obviously very talented artists working on this game. The real draw though is the drive to get all the endings and figure out the odd puzzles. The clues are there, just many of them hidden in plain sight, so to speak. I did have to use a guide to get some of the more difficult endings (I'm not nearly as patient of a gamer as I once used to be) but once you figure out a few of them, you'll start to get the hang of the puzzles. Not a whole ton of replay value unless you are going for some of the more difficult achievements, but I had a load of fun jamming away on lovely pixellated buttons for about an hour and a half. Plenty of fun nerdy gaming references abound. Definitely worth grabbing in a sale,

Having recently finished The Room (it's awesome, go play it), I was really looking forward to trying out another game with a similar play style where I could mess around with a strange device and gleefully revel in seeing how everything on it reacted. Rediscovering this in my Library and loving its premise and presentation, I couldn't wait to get stuck in and unravel its mysteries. But, sadly, it fell pretty short of expectations.

Presented with a large console adorned with a single, big, red button in its centre and a small restart switch at the bottom, you're left alone with it and given one simple instruction - don't touch anything. So, naturally, you immediately start hammering the sh*t out of the big, red button. Various kinds of interactions with it reveal an array of different switches and levers and buttons and even a mini game or two as you find out all the many ways in which you show why you can't have nice things as you completely ruin everything. For each sequence of button presses and such that you complete, you're presented with its consequence on a screen above the console, most of which are very brief little pop culture references or tips of the hat to things the makers clearly love or were inspired by (inevitably including a nod most notably toward Papers, Please which feels like a big influence on its look). And that's basically the name of the game for the hour or two it should take for you to see everything. I enjoyed my first 20 or 30 minutes of this, but the fun dried up pretty quickly after that.
